item.title: Who Is Miguel Díaz-Canel, Cuba’s New President?
item.media:description: Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez in line with his wife, Lis Cuesta, and local residents before voting in national and provincial elections in Santa Clara, Cuba, last month.
item.description: Most expect Cuba’s new president to be a leader of continuity after Raúl Castro. But he also has to figure out how to resuscitate Cuba’s economy.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: North Korea Removes Major Obstacle to U.S. Negotiations, South Says
item.media:description: American soldiers pulling dummies in Dongducheon, South Korea, this month.
item.description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, will cease to demand that U.S. troops leave South Korea as a condition for denuclearizing, the South’s president said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Damage to Great Barrier Reef From Global Warming Is Irreversible, Scientists Say
item.media:description: A diver surveying damaged coral in the Great Barrier Reef after a mass bleaching in 2016.
item.media:credit: XL Catlin Seaview Survey, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A huge heat wave killed 30 percent of the reef’s coral in 2016, and continuously high temperatures are preventing its recovery.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: Macron Had a Big Plan for Europe. It’s Now Falling Apart.
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron speaking in Épinal, France, on Tuesday. Mr. Macron’s proposed European overhaul has been hamstrung by the results of elections in Germany and Italy.
item.description: A weakened Angela Merkel, a surge in Italian populism and unresolved Brexit issues have undermined the French president’s push to reinvigorate the E.U.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Hans Asperger Aided Nazi Child Euthanasia, Study Says
item.media:description: Hans Asperger in Vienna in 1971. According to a new report, Dr. Asperger participated in the Third Reich’s child-euthanasia program.
item.description: The autism researcher collaborated with the Third Reich and actively assisted in the killing of disabled children, a new report says.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Rome Journal: ‘Shut Up, Satan’: Rome Course Teaches Exorcism, Even by Cellphone
item.media:description: “Pray without interruption” was the advice from an instructor at the 13th annual exorcism conference in Rome. The instructor also reminded the audience that “more than anything, chastity” was key.
item.description: The annual seminar seeks to train an army of exorcists to confront spreading demonic forces. Behind it is a sense that the Roman Catholic Church has gone astray.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Greek Court Upends Rules Limiting Migrants’ Movements
item.media:description: Asylum seekers from Syria and Afghanistan playing football last month at a camp on the Greek island of Lesbos.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The Council of State ruled that migrants arriving on Greek islands should no longer be held there while their asylum claims were assessed.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Frenchman Is First in World to Get 2 Full Face Transplants
item.media:description: Jérôme Hamon, left, the first person to receive two full-face transplants, with Dr. Laurent Lantieri at the Georges-Pompidou European Hospital in Paris.
item.description: Jérôme Hamon, a bookseller who has a genetic disease, underwent a second transplant after his body rejected the first because he had taken an antibiotic for a cold.
item.dc:creator: TANGUY GARREL-JAFFRELOT

item.title: Chinese Doctor Arrested, Then Applauded, for Criticizing a Popular Elixir
item.media:description: Hongmao Medical Tonic, supposedly a curative blend of 67 ingredients, on sale at a pharmacy in Shanghai.
item.description: A doctor who suggested an alcohol-based tonic was dangerous was detained for 3 months, and then freed as a public hero.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Wells Fargo, North Korea, Cuba: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and BRENT MURRAY

item.title: Big Protests in South Africa Force Ramaphosa to End London Visit
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa was in London for his first visit to a meeting of Commonwealth leaders since February, when he replaced Jacob Zuma.
item.description: The new president, Cyril Ramaphosa, has pledged to curb corruption and increase economic growth — goals vital for the political survival of the governing African National Congress.
item.dc:creator: SELAM GEBREKIDAN

item.title: Missile Strikes Are Unlikely to Stop Syria’s Chemical Attacks, Pentagon Says
item.media:description: Planning for the strike of 105 missiles on three targets — chemical weapons storage and research facilities near Damascus and Homs — took nearly a full week.
item.description: A military intelligence report found that the Syrian government is expected to resume its chemical weapons program, despite President Trump saying “mission accomplished.” Here’s how the strike unfolded.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘Fighting Very Diligently’ for 3 Americans Held by North Korea
item.media:description: People walked away after paying respects at the statues of Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il at Mansu Hill in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Sunday.
item.description: “We are doing our very best,” President Trump said of the three detainees, all Korean-Americans.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: In a Trade War, China Might Boycott U.S. Goods. That Could Backfire.
item.media:description: A Nike store in Beijing. Many of the goods that Nike and other American companies produce are assembled by Chinese workers.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: State media have hinted that Beijing could weaponize its consumers in a trade war. But American brands are popular in China — and Chinese workers make many of their products.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE and ZHANG TIANTIAN

item.title: Four Masked Burglars Steal Jade and Gold Artifacts From Museum in England
item.media:description: The thieves smashed display cases at the Museum of East Asian Art in Bath, England, and fled in a sport utility vehicle, the police said.
item.description: Witnesses reported seeing the thieves break a first-floor window on Tuesday at the Museum of East Asian Art and steal items of “priceless” significance, the police said.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: It Could Be Game Over for a Onetime King of Donkey Kong
item.media:description: Billy Mitchell in 2015. He criticized the decision to expunge his high score, saying, “This story is way, way more complicated than you could ever imagine.”
item.description: The million-point record of Billy Mitchell, the subject of a 2007 documentary, has been thrown out, and Steve Wiebe, his rival, claims “sweet victory.”
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Trump Administration Seeks to Expand Sales of Armed Drones
item.media:description: Drones like the Reaper have been the workhorse and controversial symbol of the fight against insurgents in Afghanistan and the tribal regions of Pakistan.
item.media:credit: Lt. Col. Leslie Pratt/U.S. Air Force, via Associated Press
item.description: A day after President Trump promised to slash red tape involved in weapons sales, the administration announced new policies, but experts said they would do little to speed exports.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Fidel Died and Raúl Resigned, but Castros Still Hold Sway in Cuba
item.media:description: Fidel Castro, center, clasped hands with his brother, President Raúl Castro, right, and the second secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Cuba, José Ramón Machado Ventura, at a party congress in Havana in 2016.
item.description: Stalwarts and heirs of the Communist revolution will help support — and scrutinize — Cuba’s new president, Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: The Green Card Marriage Interview: Can You Pass It?
item.media:description: Marrying an American citizen is considered a shortcut to getting a green card, but it’s not a guarantee.
item.description: Would your relationship stand up to the scrutiny of the American government? Take the test.
item.dc:creator: SHREEYA SINHA and SEAN PLAMBECK

item.title: International Herald Tribune: 1918: American Heroes Honored in France
item.media:description: Two American Lieutenants were awarded the French Croix de Guerre.
item.description: Two American lieutenants, one from Yale, the other from Harvard, received France’s Croix de Guerre for bringing down two German airplanes.
item.dc:creator: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: What to See (or Skip) in Australian Cinemas This April
item.media:description: From left, Steve Buscemi as Khrushchev, Adrian McLoughlin as Stalin (on the floor), Jeffrey Tambor as Malenkov, Dermot Crowley as Kaganovich and Simon Russell Beale as Beria in Armando Iannucci’s “The Death of Stalin.”
item.description: Not sure what movies to see in Australia this month? Let a New York Times critic help you with our film guide.
item.dc:creator: TACEY RYCHTER

item.title: Meet Me in Mongolia: How Aging Aircraft May Dictate Kim-Trump Venue
item.media:description: An Ilyushin Il-62, a Soviet airliner, in North Korea. The site options for the meeting between the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, and President Trump are limited.
item.description: Kim Jong-un is not known to have flown outside his country, and the question of his transportation complicates an already delicate and uncertain meeting.
item.dc:creator: ALI WATKINS

item.title: Life After Castro: Who Is Cuba’s Next President?
item.description: As Raúl Castro of Cuba steps down, Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez steps up. Here’s a look at Mr. Castro’s handpicked successor and what’s ahead for the communist country.

item.title: North Korea, Southwest Airlines, Barbara Bush: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Letter 54: Award-Winning Journalism for Globally Minded Australians
item.media:description: Harvey Weinstein.
item.description: A selection of Pulitzer projects from The New York Times, from the past year and our archives.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Riyadh Journal: Cinema Ban Lifts as ‘Black Panther’ Is Screened for Saudi Audience
item.media:description: Audiences were entertained by mimes and actors on Wednesday at the first public movie screening in Saudi Arabia after a decades-long ban.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: A V.I.P. screening of the Hollywood blockbuster “Black Panther” in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, marked the end of a decades-old ban on movie theaters.
item.dc:creator: TASNEEM ALSULTAN and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: 8 Decades of British Royal Corgis Reportedly at an End
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II with her corgis in 1973. The House of Windsor came by its first corgi four decades earlier, in 1933.
item.description: Amid reports that Queen Elizabeth II’s last beloved dog, Willow, has died, here’s a look at royal corgis in real life and pop culture.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GOLD
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Gunmen Shot at U.N. Team Near Site of Reported Chemical Attack, Official Says
item.media:description: A team of international experts is trying to determine whether chemical weapons were used in an attack on the Syrian town of Douma that killed at least 43 people this month.
item.description: The head of the organization investigating the reported chemical attack in Douma, Syria, said it was unclear when investigators would visit the site.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons

item.title: Why the French Are Growing Angry With Emmanuel Macron
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France was interviewed by Jean-Jacques Bourdin of RMC-BFM, right, and Edwy Plenel of Mediapart, in Paris on Sunday.
item.description: Less than a year into France’s new presidency, anti-Macron sentiment is emerging as a potent force.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Pressed by Hard-Liners, U.S.-Trained Environmentalist Quits Post in Iran
item.media:description: Kaveh Madani
item.description: The resignation of the environmentalist, Kaveh Madani, was a blow to President Hassan Rouhani, who has encouraged Iranian experts abroad to come home.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Top Porsche Official Targeted in German Police Raid Tied to Diesel Scheme
item.media:description: Police officers raiding the offices of the sports car maker Porsche in Stuttgart, Germany, on Wednesday as part of a widening inquiry into diesel-emissions cheating centered on Porsche’s parent company, Volkswagen.
item.media:credit: Sina Schuldt/Deutsche Presse-Agentur, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The authorities searched the Stuttgart offices of the sports car maker, one of Volkswagen’s most profitable units, and said a Porsche board member was a suspect in an emissions-cheating scandal.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Raúl Castro Prepares to Resign as Cuba’s President, Closing a Dynasty
item.media:description: President Raúl Castro, left, taking part in a session of the National Assembly in Havana on Wednesday.
item.description: Without the Castro legacy to rely on, his successor will face a minefield of tasks that even Mr. Castro failed to complete.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Russia Tried to Shut Down Telegram. Websites Were Collateral Damage.
item.media:description: Demonstrators threw paper airplanes — the corporate symbol for Telegram — in front of the Moscow headquarters of the F.S.B., Russia’s secret police, to protest a ban on the popular messaging app.
item.description: Attempts by the country’s internet watchdog to impose a ban on the popular messaging app were opposed by, among others, Edward J. Snowden and a member of Pussy Riot.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Top Finance Official in Japan Resigns Over Harassment Accusations
item.media:description: Junichi Fukuda, the administrative vice minister in Japan’s Finance Ministry, said accusations that he had sexually harassed female journalists were “not factual.”
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Junichi Fukuda has denied the allegations. But his resignation was a sign that Japan might be joining the international reckoning in the #MeToo movement.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Did Soldiers Jailed for Killings Go Free? Myanmar TV Says Yes (Briefly)
item.media:description: A photograph said to show 10 Rohingya Muslims before their killing in the village of Inn Din, Myanmar, in September.
item.description: Seven Myanmar military personnel convicted in a massacre of Rohingya Muslims went free in a mass amnesty, a TV station said. The report was quickly taken down.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: If North Korea Talks Are Not Fruitful, ‘I Will Respectfully Leave,’ Trump Says
item.media:description: President Trump with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan on Wednesday at Mar-a-Lago, Fla. The president continued to express optimism about sitting down with the leader of North Korea.
item.description: As the momentum grows for a meeting with the North Korean leader, President Trump acknowledged that it was a risky undertaking, and one that could still end in failure.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Total, With Energy Industry in Flux, Makes $1.7 Billion Bet on a Utility
item.media:description: Total, the French energy giant, has been looking to diversify from its traditional oil and gas pursuits.
item.description: The deal fits what appears to be an accelerating trend, as oil and gas companies invest in a wide range of activities, particularly in cleaner energy.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED

item.title: Erdogan Calls Early Turkish Elections in Bid to Solidify Power
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey at a news conference in Ankara on Wednesday. He has been trying to increase the authority of the presidency in his country.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey called for voting on June 24, 18 months earlier than had been expected, citing instability in Syria and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Treaty to Formally End Korean War Is Being Discussed, South Confirms
item.media:description: Chung Eui-yong, second from left, the South Korean president’s national security adviser, visiting Washington last week.
item.description: South Korea said it had been in talks with both American and North Korean officials about replacing the 1953 armistice with a full peace agreement.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Japan Fears Being Sidelined by Trump on Trade and North Korea
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on Tuesday. Despite their close alliance, the United States has been acting independently of Japan on matters like North Korea.
item.description: Dogged by scandal at home, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is hoping to score diplomatic and political victories during a meeting this week with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: South Africa to Investigate 2 A.N.C. Officials in Farm Corruption Case
item.media:description: Ace Magashule, secretary general of the African National Congress, was the premier of the province of Free State from 2009 to this year.
item.description: The inquiry will focus on senior African National Congress politicians, signaling that party figures could answer for abuses under former President Jacob Zuma.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI and SELAM GEBREKIDAN

item.title: How an Alleged Sonic Attack Shaped U.S. Policy on Cuba
item.description: In 2016, diplomats at the United States Embassy in Havana were mysteriously stricken. Was it an attack? There is no official explanation, but the episode has played a big role in America’s current political disengagement with Cuba.

item.title: China Conducts War Games, and Taiwan Is the Target
item.media:description: Chinese state media released this photo from the country’s largest naval exercises in decades, carried out last week off Hainan Island. An analyst compared those exercises to a military parade, but she said China’s live-fire drills Wednesday in the Taiwan Strait were “a warning.”
item.description: The live-fire drills in the Taiwan Strait come as China and the United States are at odds over the self-governing island, which Beijing considers its territory.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: C.I.A. Chief’s Meeting With Kim Jong-un Is Latest Step in Winding Path to Talks
item.media:description: A photo released by North Korea’s state news agency showing Kim Jong-un, center, and other leaders marking the birth anniversary of the country’s founder, Kim Il-sung, in Pyongyang on Sunday.
item.description: A meeting between North Korea’s leader and President Trump would be the highest-level talks between the two countries, but there is a long history of failed efforts.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and EMILY COCHRANE

item.title: Australia Diary: Weathering the Weather
item.media:description: Satellite imagery of one of the many cyclones to hit Queensland, Australia.
item.description: Growing up in Queensland means understanding the difference between hot, stinking hot and unbearably hot.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: The Fight With the West Is Isolating Russia. But That Isn’t Stopping Putin.
item.media:description: An exchange office in Moscow last week. Russia is likely to suffer long-term economic damage as a result of President Vladimir V. Putin’s aggressive posture toward the West.
item.description: Sanctions are increasingly isolating Russia and damaging its economy, but President Vladimir V. Putin and his supporters are confident things are going well.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Mike Pompeo, C.I.A. Director, Met With Kim Jong-un in North Korea
item.media:description: President Trump during his meeting on Tuesday with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan.
item.description: The president alluded to the mission on Tuesday when he said that the United States was in direct talks with North Korea at “extremely high levels.”
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Israel Celebrates Its 70th Israeli Style: With Rancor and Bickering
item.media:description: An Israeli Air Force aerobatic team rehearsing on Monday for Israel’s 70th Independence Day celebration.
item.description: Some said the ruckus over Israel’s 70th anniversary party was crass and undignified. Others said it was perfectly, quintessentially Israel.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
